name: Vitamin K
summary: Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin essential for blood clotting, bone metabolism, and vascular health. It exists primarily in two forms: K1 (phylloquinone) from plants and K2 (menaquinones) produced by bacteria or found in animal-based foods.
description: Vitamin K is crucial for the activation of clotting factors (II, VII, IX, X) and proteins involved in bone and vascular health. Vitamin K1 (phylloquinone) is found mainly in leafy green vegetables, while vitamin K2 (menaquinones, MK-4 to MK-13) comes from fermented foods, meats, and gut bacteria. Supplementation is used to treat deficiency, prevent bleeding disorders, and support bone health. Vitamin K antagonists (e.g., warfarin) interfere with its action, requiring careful monitoring of intake. Emerging evidence suggests a role in reducing vascular calcification and supporting cardiovascular health, particularly for K2.

metadata.natural_source: Leafy green vegetables (K1), fermented foods (natto, cheese), meats, eggs, gut bacteria (K2)
metadata.prescription_status: OTC (dietary supplement); prescription formulations available for deficiency

primary_indications: Prevention and treatment of vitamin K deficiency
Prevention of hemorrhagic disease of the newborn
Reversal of anticoagulation from vitamin K antagonists (warfarin)
contraindications: Use with caution in patients on anticoagulant therapy (interferes with dosing balance)
monitoring_required: Prothrombin time (PT) / INR, especially in patients on warfarin

items: Bleeding disorders due to deficiency or warfarin therapy
Prevention of hemorrhagic disease of the newborn

sections.text: Vitamin K acts as a cofactor for gamma-glutamyl carboxylase, which modifies clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X and proteins C and S, enabling calcium binding and proper function. It also activates osteocalcin and matrix Gla protein, contributing to bone health and inhibition of vascular calcification.

adult.deficiency treatment: 2.5–25 mg orally or subcutaneously, depending on severity
adult.warfarin reversal: 1–10 mg orally or IV depending on INR and bleeding risk

sections.text: Onset of action: 6–12 hours orally, faster with IV administration. Duration depends on clotting factor synthesis, typically 12–48 hours.

common: Generally well tolerated at dietary levels
serious: Hypersensitivity reactions (rare, usually with IV administration)
Hemolytic anemia and hyperbilirubinemia in neonates (with synthetic menadione, no longer recommended)

other: Do not use menadione (synthetic K3) due to toxicity.
High doses can interfere with anticoagulant therapy (warfarin).
IV administration carries rare but serious risk of anaphylaxis; oral route preferred when possible.

items.with: Warfarin and other vitamin K antagonists

items.risk: May reduce gut flora vitamin K production, increasing deficiency risk

sections.pregnancy: Safe at dietary levels; higher doses used for neonatal prophylaxis
sections.pediatrics: Neonatal prophylaxis standard of care; deficiency can cause life-threatening bleeding
sections.geriatrics: Safe at recommended levels; monitor anticoagulant interactions

sections.text: Not required; supplementation can be adjusted based on dietary intake and INR monitoring if on anticoagulants.

items: Vitamin K deficiency is rare in healthy adults due to dietary intake and gut microbiota contribution.
K2 (especially MK-7 from natto) may have longer half-life and greater efficacy in bone and vascular health, though clinical data are emerging.
Routine supplementation beyond RDA is not recommended except for specific conditions (e.g., warfarin reversal, deficiency, neonatal prophylaxis).
